name: Temminck's Tragopan
description: Male tragopans lack long tail feathers but boast blue wattled outgrowths on their heads, resembling horns and giving them their name. During courtship, they inflate a blue, leathery throat lappet that unfurls over their chest like a colorful bib. Females are brown with white spots and a blue patch around the eyes.
spread_note: Northern South Asia, from northeastern India to northern China
food_note: Invertebrates, berries, buds, and other plant parts
proportions: Body length 41–45.5 cm; tail length 18.5–23 cm; wing length 22–26 cm; weight 1–1.4 kg
attractions: Tragopans are distinctly mountain birds, found at altitudes up to 4,000 m above sea level. Unlike most pheasants, they are primarily folivorous, and both parents carry food to their chicks in the tips of their beaks. Their nest, built from twigs, is placed above ground, sometimes as high as 8 m.
breeding: We first kept tragopans from 1956 to 1961, then in the 1980s, and more recently since 2004.
localities_title: Sichuan - Pavilion of Birds from the Himalayan Foothills
